question: Incredible... These are the same coordinates before the ship disappeared... this, this happened? This isn't some kind of hoax?
answer: I wouldn't bring you here on a hoax. Houston confirms the telemetry and I.D. codes.

question: It's the Event Horizon. She's come back.
answer: That ship was lost in deep space, seven years ago. If the Titanic sailed into New York harbor, I'd find it more plausible. Houston wants Aerospace to send out a search and rescue team, investigate the source of the transmission. If it really is the Event Horizon, they'll attempt a salvage. We need you to prepare a detailed briefing on the ship's systems for the salvage crew...

question: A written briefing can't possibly anticipate the variables on a mission like this. I have to go with them.
answer: Dr. Weir, you have no experience with salvage procedures.

question: I designed the ship's propulsion system. I am the only person capable of evaluating the performance of the gravity drive. You can't send a Search and Rescue team out there alone and expect them to succeed. That would be like... like sending an auto- mechanic to work on the shuttle.
answer: I can understand your desire to redeem your reputation, Dr. Weir, but it doesn't factor into this.

question: Don't thank me, Bill. I'm not doing you any favors.
answer: You're not seriously considering sending him?

question: You don't just dismiss Bill Weir. The man held Oppenheimer's chair at Princeton. If the Event Horizon had worked, he would have gone down in history as the greatest mind in physics since Einstein.
answer: The official inquiry blamed Weir's design for the ship's loss.

question: That doesn't mean a damn thing. They were looking for a scapegoat and Weir fit the bill. But he's not responsible for what happened to the ship.
answer: Does he know that?

question: What's on your mind?
answer: He doesn't belong on this mission. Responsible or not, he blames himself. He's too close to it. And then there's his wife.

question: It's been two years since she died. He's over it.
answer: Some things you don't get over.

question: I want our best people on this. Where's Miller?
answer: The Lewis and Clark just returned from patrol in the asteroid belt, she's docked in bay four.

question: The clock is running, Dr. Weir. If you'll follow the rest of the crew, they'll show you to the gravity tanks. What's the hold up?
answer: Just loading the last of the CO2 scrubbers. Good for four months.

question: I put in for a replacement for you but no one...
answer: No, no, its alright. I talked to my ex, he'll keep Denny over Christmas and I'll get him this summer. Goddam it, Skipper... I haven't seen him in two months.

question: First time in a grav couch?
answer: Yes.

question: Don't worry about it. He's hard, but he's fair. You're lucky to be shipping out with him. He's one of the few Captains in the service with experience in the Outer Reach.
answer: He's been past Mars?

question: He served on the Goliath.
answer: Wasn't that ship destroyed?

question: Damn, Dr. Weir, don't scare us like that. Coffee?
answer: What?

question: Coffee.
answer: No, thank you.

question: Matching speed... now. Range to target ten thousand meters and closing... Skipper, I got a bad feeling about this...
answer: We're all on edge, Smith. We're a long way out...

question: That's not it. That ship was built to go faster than light... That's just wrong, it goes against everything we know...
answer: What are you trying to say? "If God had intended Man to fly, he would have given us wings?"

question: Something like that, yeah.
answer: I guess we're about to find out. Keep us slow and steady.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Dr. Weir...! I think you want to see this.

question: Affirmative. The hull's intact... but there's no gravity and the thermal units are off line. I'm showing deep cold. The crew couldn't survive unless they were in stasis.
answer: Find 'em, Starck.

question: Something's wrong with the bio-scan.
answer: Radiation interference?

question: Dr. Weir, I need you on the bridge.
answer: Captain, I didn't come out here to sit on your bridge, I need to be on that ship...

question: Once the ship is secured, we'll bring you on board --
answer: That is not acceptable --

question: -- once we've secured the ship, that's the way it is! I need you to guide us from the comm station. This is where I need you. Help us to do our job.
answer: Very well.

question: ...do you copy?
answer: Uh, yeah Coop, I'm still here.

question: Shit! Do not do that! Where the fuck are you?
answer: I'm in the Second Containment area. It's pitch black in here. There must have been a coolant leak. Man, this shit is everywhere. I can't see a damn thing. The reactor's still hot. Coolant level is on reserve, but still in the green. I got it... Holy shit...

question: Justin?
answer: I think I found something...

question: We lost the starboard baffle and the hull cracked. Our safety seals didn't close, the circuit's fried --
answer: Do we have enough time for a weld?

question: We don't have time to fart. We're losing pressure at 280 liters a second and our oxygen tanks are cracked. In three minutes, our atmosphere will be gone. We are fucking dead.
answer: No one's dying on my watch, Smith! What about the reserve tanks?

question: The antennae array's completely fried, we've got no radio, no laser, no highgain... No one's going to be coming to help us.
answer: How much oh-two do we have?

question: Oxygen is not the problem.
answer: Carbon dioxide?

question: It's building up with every breath we take. And the CO2 filters on the Event Horizon are shot.
answer: We can take the filters from the Clark...

question: I thought of that, with the filters from the Clark, we've got enough breathable air for twenty hours. After that, we'd better be on our way home.
answer: What about the life readings you picked up?

question: The Event Horizon sensors show the same thing
answer: What's causing the readings?

question: I don't know, but whatever it is, it's not the crew.
answer: So where is the rest of the crew? We've been over every inch of this ship and all we've found is blood. Dr. Weir? Any suggestions? What happened here?

question: Captain Miller, you copy?
answer: I'm here, Smith, how's the Clark?

question: I've found a six inch fracture in the outer hull. We should be able to repair it and re-pressurize, it's gonna take some time.
answer: We don't have time, Smith. In twenty hours we run out of air.

question: Understood.
answer: How is he?

question: Fine. Starck, I want you to repeat the bio-scan...
answer: What's the point? I'll just get the same thing...

question: Not acceptable. I want to know what's causing those readings. If the crew is dead, I want the bodies, I want the crew found.
answer: I can reconfigure the scan for C-12, amylase proteins.

question: Hold on, what's this "gravitational distortion?"
answer: It's possible that a burst of gravity waves escaped from the Core, distorting space-time. They could be what hit the Lewis and Clark.

question: What could cause them? What's in the Core?
answer: It's complicated...

question: How much time do you need? We have seventeen hours and forty-two minutes. Now
answer: A black hole.

question: It's insane.
answer: "Insane?" The finest astronauts fought to be posted to this ship. It would take the Lewis and Clark a thousand years to reach our closest star. The Event Horizon could be there in a day...

question: If it worked.
answer: If it worked, yes.

question: I want this room sealed. The Second Containment is off limits.
answer: There's no danger. The black hole is contained behind three magnetic fields, it's under control.

question: You been out there a long time. Trying to break my record?
answer: I'd rather spend the next twelve hours Outside than another five minutes in this can. This ship is bad. It watches you.

question: What?
answer: You heard me. This ship, it's crazy

question: Shit, Smith, you're going Biblical on me.
answer: You know what happened to the Tower of Babel, don't you? It fell down.

question: Why Dr. Weir, I think you're in love.
answer: Hmmm. Claire used to tell me I loved the Event Horizon more than I loved her. I told her that wasn't true, I just knew the Event Horizon better, that's all.

question: Claire is your wife?
answer: Yes.

question: It must be hard, being so far away from her.
answer: Yes. I miss her. She died. Two years now.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: These things happen. Wait a minute, that's not right...

question: These things happen. Wait a minute, that's not right...
answer: You have something, Dr. Weir?

question: The date.
answer: What about it?

question: The Event Horizon's computer think's it's 2034.
Goddammit, DJ, it was not a hallucination! I saw a man, he was on fire. And then he disappeared.
answer: Maybe one of the original crew?

question: No. It was someone else.
answer: Who?

question: Miller...
answer: What is it, Starck?

question: ...I ran the bio-scan with the DNA/RNA filter. The results were bio-readings of indeterminate origin...
answer: "...bio-readings of indeterminate origin," don't you have anything useful to tell me?

question: I've got a theory.
answer: Go ahead.

question: There was a another surge in the bio- readings right before you... you saw what you saw. We picked up a similar readings right before the Clarke was damaged. What if there were a connection between the two? The gravity waves, the hallucination, all part of an defensive reaction, like an immune system...
answer: I don't need to hear this.

question: You've got to listen...
answer: To what? What are you saying? This ship is alive?

question: I didn't say that, I said the bio- readings correspond to what happened to you, the ship is reacting to us...
answer: We're hanging on by our fingernails and you're giving me bullshit stories...

question: It's not bullshit, it's the only conclusion the data supports...
answer: Starck, do you know how crazy that sounds? It's impossible.

question: I know that.
answer: If you knew it was impossible, then why'd you waste my time?

question: I thought you wanted an answer. And that's the only one I have.
answer: What I want is to survive the next ten hours.

question: Nine hours and twenty-two minutes.
answer: I'm going outside to work on the Clark. And Starck... don't tell anyone what you just told me. We've got enough to worry about.

question: What are you doing?
answer: It wants me. I have to go.

question: No...! In our current environment, Dr. Weir, self-control is an asset.
answer: I'm alright. Please.

question: What is it?
answer: The forward airlock.

question: What, Justin, what shows you?
answer: It won't stop, it goes on and on and on...

question: What does?
answer: The dark inside me. ...It's inside and it eats and eats until there's nothing left.

question: "The dark inside..."? I don't understand.
answer: From the Other Place... The other crew, they're there, they're waiting for me. They're waiting for you. I won't go back there... I won't...

question: Come on, Baby-bear, open this door...
answer: If you could see the things I've seen, you wouldn't try to stop me. You'd come with me.

question: NOOO!
answer: Hey, Mama-Bear... what are doing...? Oh my god OH MY GOD...

question: Patch me through to him. Justin.
answer: Skipper, you gotta help me... ...tell them to open the door...

question: They can't do that Justin, now listen carefully...
answer: ...I don't want to die...!

question: You're not going to die! Not today! I want you to do exactly as I say and I'm gonna get you out of there, alright?
answer: But I can't... I gotta get out of here... Skipper, please...

question: Justin. I won't let you die.
answer: Okay... okay...

question: Oh God... Justin... I've got a pulse, he's alive...
answer: Pressure?

question: 90 over 50 and falling... .
answer: He's crashing... He can breathe. That's good. Let's get him to Medical, go, go! Intubate, pure oxygen feed, get the nitrogen out of his blood...

question: His peritoneum has ruptured...
answer: One thing at a time, let's keep him breathing. Start the drip, 15cc's fibrinogen, Christ, he's bleeding out... He'll live... if we ever make it back.

question: I don't remember saying that. Maybe I'm insane, too.
answer: I want to know what caused that noise. I want to know why one of my crew tried to throw himself out of the airlock.

question: Thermal changes in the hull could have caused the metal to expand and contract very suddenly, causing reverberations --
answer: That's bullshit and you know it! You built this fucking ship and all I've heard from you is bullshit!

question: What do you want me to say?
answer: You said this ship creates a gateway...

question: Yes...
answer: To what? Where did this ship go? Where did you send it?

question: I don't know...
answer: Where has it been for the past seven years?

question: I don't know...
answer: The "Other Place," what is that...?

question: I DON'T KNOW! I don't know. There's a lot of things going on here that I don't understand. Truth takes time.
answer: That's exactly what we don't have, Doctor.

question: Any change?
answer: No. No change. I've analyzed Justin's blood samples. There's no evidence of excessive levels of carbon dioxide. Or anything else out of ordinary.

question: Of course not. Justin just climbed into the airlock because he felt like it. Just one of those things. I swore I'd never lose another man. I came close today. Real close.
answer: "Another man?" Who?

question: It was on the Goliath. There was this bosun, Corrick, a young guy, a lot like Justin. Edmund Corrick, from Decatur, Georgia. He got caught when the pressure doors sealed, one closed on his arm. Severed it at the wrist. The pain of that must have been... He passed out and... I, I tried to go back for him, to save him, but I couldn't get to him in time. The fire... Have you ever seen fire in zero-gravity? It's like a liquid, it slides over everything. It was like a wave breaking over him, a wave of fire. And then he was gone. I never told anyone until now. But this ship knew, DJ. It knows about the Goliath, it knows about Corrick. It knows our secrets. It knows what we're afraid of. And now you're going to tell me it's carbon dioxide.
answer: No.

question: What is it?
answer: I've been listening to the transmission. And I think Houston made a mistake in the translation.

question: Go on.
answer: They thought it said, "Liberatis me," "Save me," but it's not "me." It's "tutemet:" "Save yourself."

question: It's not a distress call. It's a warning.
answer: It gets worse. It's very hard to make out, but listen to this final part. Do you hear it? Right there.

question: Hear what?
answer: It sounds like "ex infera:" "ex," from; "infera," the ablative case of "inferi." "Hell."

question: "Save yourself. From Hell." What are you saying, are you saying that this ship is possessed?
answer: No. I don't believe in that sort of thing. But if Dr. Weir is right, this ship has passed beyond the boundaries of our universe, of reality. Who knows where this ship has been... What it's seen... And what it's brought back with it.

question: We're leaving.
answer: You can't, your orders are specific...

question: "...to rescue the crew and salvage the ship." The crew is dead, Dr. Weir. This ship killed them. And now it's killing us.
answer: You're insane. You've lost your mind.

question: Maybe you're right. But it's still my command, and I have leeway to abort when I feel there is an unacceptable threat to my crew. And I think there is. Starck, download all the files from the Event Horizon's computers. Coop, Smith, finish moving the CO2 scrubbers back onto the Clark.
answer: Don't... don't do this...

question: What about my ship?
answer: We will take the Lewis and Clark to a safe distance and then launch tac missiles at the Event Horizon until I am satisfied that she has been destroyed. Fuck this ship.

question: You... You can't do that!
answer: Watch me.

question: Goddammit! Starck, get those files and vacate. I want off this ship.
answer: You can't leave. She won't let you.

question: Just get your gear back onto the Lewis and Clark, doctor, or you'll find yourself looking for a ride home.
answer: I am home.

question: Thank you.
answer: Captain, we got a problem.

question: Now what?
answer: She was right behind me, I turn around, she's gone. She could be anywhere.

question: Claire stands naked before the bathroom mirror. Behind her, the tub steams... ...and in the bathroom, she clutches Weir's straight-razor...
answer: She reaches down. Slowly, her arms cradle his head. She slides down on him. Straddles him.

question: ...Claire slips into the steaming water...
answer: He raises his head to her breasts. His eyes, closed. She remains unnaturally still, only her hips rocking back and forth.

question: ...and the razor bites her skin...
answer: She caresses his face. Lifts his face to hers. Her mouth is slack. Her hair hangs in front of her eyes.

question: ...Claire floats dead in the red water, eyes open, hair billowing around her head like a halo...
answer: Weir gazes up at her, transfixed. He takes her hand and raises it to his face. She caresses his cheek. And reaches for his eyes...

question: Skipper...
answer: What is it, Smith?

question: I just saw Weir, I think he was messing around on the Clark.
answer: Smith, get out of there...

question: Come again, Skipper?
answer: One of the explosives is missing from the corridor. I think Weir may have put it on the Clark. Get off the Clark now and wait for me at the airlock.

question: No, no, we just got her back together...
answer: Get out of there now!

question: Where is it, where is it...
answer: Smith? Smith! Fuck!

question: I gotcha... I gotcha... I gotcha.
answer: NOOO! DJ. The Clark's gone. Smith and Cooper are dead.

question: Oh my God.
answer: Please...

question: Oh, God, DJ, what do I... how do
answer: Please... kill...

question: We've got to shut it down, we've got to...
answer: How? The Bridge is gone.

question: There must be a way! What about Engineering?
answer: Can you shut it down?

question: I don't know the process, Dr. Weir was the expert...
answer: I don't want to go where the last crew went. I'd rather be dead.

question: We blow the Corridor. Use the foredecks as a lifeboat, separate it from the rest of the ship. We stay put...
answer: ...and the gravity drive goes where no man has gone before.

question: You prep the gravity couches. I'm going to manually arm those explosives.
answer: Will it work?

question: Do you remember me?
answer: Corrick...

question: You left me behind.
answer: That's not true...

question: I begged you. I begged you to save me and you did nothing. You stood there and watched me burn...
answer: SHUT UP! SHUT UP!

question: You're not Edmund Corrick. What are you?
answer: You know.

question: You want me to believe you're the Devil, well, I don't, that's bullshit!
answer: I'm not the Devil.

question: Then what, what are you? Tell me...
answer: Better if I just show you.

question: NO! You can't have them!
answer: I'm not the Devil. I'm much, much older. I watched the Beginning and I will see the End. I am the dark behind the stars. I am the dark inside you all.

question: ...not the Devil...
answer: There is no Devil. There is no God. There is only... NOTHING.

question: You're lying...!
answer: I'm not asking you to believe me. You'll see for yourself... and so will your crew. You're all coming with me.

question: Starck... Cooper...
answer: They are mine. And so are you...

question: You can't have them. Go to hell.
answer: NOOO!
